Knowledge Point: The compounds that these combinations create are mostly intransitive verbs with often idiosyncratic meanings: vwa vua lit. \qu{do net}, \qu{throw a net}. Vwa uvu \qu{do yam}, \qu{wind yam sprouts around a tutor}, vwa xhwaeo \qu{do taro}, \qu{harvest taro}. Undergoers would be added as oblique arguments with ko \qu{\gl{obl}}, see example (\ref{ex:vwa_ko}). Since vwa is semantically vague and thus readily used as a filler verb, new compounds are often formed (e.g. vwa toki \qu{do metal}, \qu{make a telephone call}), established compounds can broken up ad hoc into verb phrases with specific arguments (see example \ref{ex:vwa_ref}) and many remain transparent phrases. With few exceptions, this grammar will thus avoid marking vwa-constructions clearly as compounds by connecting vwa to its modifier or argument. \sectref{sec:ZeroTrans} takes a closer look at intransitive verbs.
Content 1: \gll goagt=vwa-vua ko [i=vuman nyu]obl nya-xahut | \gls 2SG=do-net OBL DEF.SG=group fish send-down.there | \glt You cast-net upon the fish school down there.
Content 2: \gll goagt=vwa li=xhwaeop nya-an | \gls 2SG=do DEF.PL=taro towards-same.level | \glt You harvest the taros over there.

Knowledge Point: Vamale's wealth in different classes of morphemes is mirrored on the phonological level: phonological units overlap or not with syntactic units, and the latter can be derived and re-analyzed relatively easily, compare (\ref{ex:rea1}) to (\ref{ex:rea2}). %For example, nouns that are alienably possessed are marked with -n \qu{\gl{poss}}. When the possessor is indexed via a personal possessive suffix (1\gl{sg} etc.) rather than a noun, the possessed noun takes the suffixes -n-eong, -n-go, -n-gau,\ldots See \Cref{tab:morph_overview} for a complete list.
Content 1: \gll hnyimake (eca)=aman | \gls think.about INDF.SG=thing | \glt think about something.
Content 2: \gll i=hnyimake-aman | \gls DEF.SG=think-thing | \glt the thinking of something

Section: The distinction between verbs and nouns
Knowledge Point: A common problem in Oceanic linguistics concerns the distinction between verbs and nouns, which can be considered blurry. A verb phrase can be nominalized just by putting an article in front of it, after which it functions as an argument. A noun phrase can be used as a predicate, and preceded by aspect and modality markers. As discussed by \textcite[3]{creissels_non-verbal_}, one can distinguish three types of non-verbal predicates: nominal, adjectival, and locative. Vamale has no adjectives, but nominal and locative predicates are well attested. example (\ref{ex:le_niehni}) is an example of a pronominal predicate, (\ref{ex:ca_i_bureau}) shows a predicative locative noun phrase, composed of a prepositional noun ca \qu{in} and a common noun, and a nominal predicate is shown in (\ref{ex:predN}).
Content 1: \gll li=bee-m, le=niehni | \gls DEF.PL=peer-2SG.POSS 3PL=all.those | \glt Your friends, they are those over there.
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gll go=bo i=daahma | \gls 2SG=IRR DEF.SG=chief | \glt You would be chief.

Section: The distinction between verbs and nouns
Knowledge Point: Within a noun phrase, modifiers are either nominalized verbs that precede the noun, as in (\ref{ex:WCadj1}), possessors, or relative clauses, as in (\ref{ex:WCadj2}). Verbal modifiers are either adverbs or adverbial clauses, or verbs that integrate the verb phrase.
Content 1: \gll i=bwaakala a=xhopwen | \gls DEF.SG=boat REL=big | \glt the big boat
Content 2: \gll i=joakan sapwen | \gls DEF.SG=thick dress | \glt the thick dress

Section: The distinction between verbs and nouns
Knowledge Point: Reflexive/reciprocal e-, mostly found on verbs, also occurs with nouns in predicate function, as shown in (\ref{ex:refl_nouns}–\ref{ex:refl_nouns2}). This is a relatively rare occurrence and was only attested with a reciprocal meaning.
Content 1: \gll lu=e-copain-copine | \gls 3DU=RECP-boyfriend-girlfriend | \glt The two are boyfriend and girlfriend.
Content 2: \gll calibeen ma le=moo ma li=ehni, e-bee-le | \gls sometimes SUBR 3PL=stay COM DEF.PL=DEM.PROX RECP-peer-3PL.POSS | \glt Sometimes when they stay together with those, they are each other's cousins.

Section: The distinction between verbs and nouns
Knowledge Point: Some particles and affixes, however, mark the resulting construction as definitely verbal. This includes causative fa-, transitive markers -ke and -i, and manner prefixes (discussed in \sectref{sec:Manner}). For example, xhaavwa in (\ref{ex:xhavwa}) has a different stem than xhavwaleke in (\ref{ex:xhavwaleke}), both in vowel quantity and the last syllable -le.
Content 1: \gll e=xhaavwa | \gls 1SG=wait | \glt I'm waiting around.
Content 2: \gll e=xhavwale-ke (aman) | \gls 1SG=wait.for-TR something | \glt I'm waiting for something.

Section: The distinction between verbs and nouns
Knowledge Point: The suffix -n \qu{\gl{nspec}, \gl{ana}} warrants an early introduction, as it occurs across word classes, affecting dependent verbs, prepositional nouns and regular inalienable nouns alike. In essence, -n has two functions: one is to mark the generic nature of the argument of its verbal host (\ref{ex:verbal-n}), or the generic possessor of its nominal host (\ref{ex:nominal-n}), while the other function is anaphoric or cataphoric. Generic nouns do not take an article, whereas specific nouns take definite or indefinite articles (see \sectref{sec:WCArticles}).
Content 1: \gll ka na naen cipa hmwaka-n habu | \gls CNJ DEM now NEG be.like-NSPEC long.ago | \glt But this is today, not like [things were) yesterday.
Content 2: \gll kon th=e ra-ta-meebam nyeca-n sohmun | \gls then ASS=1SG NMLZ-be.sitting-sleep inside-NSPEC school | \glt You must know that I kept sleeping on my chair at school.

Section: The distinction between verbs and nouns
Knowledge Point: %Two other suffixes -n must be mentioned: in noun phrases, a suffix -n indexes inalienable 3\gl{sg} possessors on the possessed noun, be it specific (\ref{ex:inalienable}) or generic (\ref{ex:nspec}). Another suffix -n serves as an alienable possessum-marking construct suffix (no indication of person), as in (\ref{ex:alienable}) (see \sectref{sec:Poss} for a more detailed discussion). The two -n are distinguished on the basis of their different distribution. Inalienable -n \qu{3\gl{sg}.\gl{poss}} is part of a paradigm of possessive pronoun marking suffixes, excluding a possessor NP following, while the construct suffix has no allomorphs, grammatically conditioned or otherwise, and occurs between a nominal possessor and its possessum. As the (in)alienability of nouns is lexically conditioned, the two suffixes do not contrast on the same word.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Section: The distinction between verbs and nouns
Knowledge Point: \is{Anaphoric -n}The other function mentioned above is anaphora in the wider sense: relating to something already mentioned (\ref{ex:n_ana}), mentioned in another clause soon after, or known in general (\ref{ex:hmwaana_koon}). The referent's specificity is not important in this case. %The syntactic roles avalailable to the participant indexed with -n are lower ones: objects, the modifiers of prepositional phrases, and, in the case of nominalizations featuring ka-n, intransitive or inanimate subjects.
Content 1: \gll ehni xhwan da, abe=fate gavwe koo-\textbf{n} go abe=sate-\textbf{n}, cipa hmai-n, cipa-bu ju-vaa udu hmwaka-u | \gls PROX little what 1PL.EXCL=share 2PL OBL-ANA then 1PL.EXCL=be.different-ANA NEG be.many-NSPEC NEG-1DU.EXCL real-too drink like-2DU | \glt This [wine and beer) is nothing much, we share with you of this, and [as for) us, it's different, not much, we don't drink as hard as you do.
Content 2: \gll hmwaa-na koo-n! | \gls like-DIST on-ANA | \glt Like that!/Now that's a proper way of doing it!

Knowledge Point: Vamale makes the wide-spread distinction between singular, dual and plural (see \Cref{tab:articles}), and what this study considers to be degrees of definiteness rather than specificity (an argument for this analysis follows in \sectref{ssec:WCArt_specificity}). Using a noun phrase without an article makes it non-specific, as seen in (\ref{ex:noArt2}) and (\ref{ex:Art2}).
Content 1: \gll go=han can hnyimake thamo | \gls 2SG=walk SUBR think woman | \glt You walk while thinking about a woman.
Content 2: \gll go=han can hnyimake i=thamo | \gls 2SG=walk SUBR think DEF.SG=woman | \glt You walk while thinking about the woman.

Knowledge Point: Vamale speakers can choose between using an article (the noun thus having a specific referent) (see \ref{ex:Art}), and not using an article (see \ref{ex:noArt}, \ref{ex:gen}), in which case the noun is generic. In oft-used expressions, the verb forms a compound with the noun.\footnote{See \textcite{ozanne-rivierre_verbal_2004} for a discussion of similar phenomena in other New Caledonian languages.}
Content 1: \gll e=xaleke i=apuli a=a=xhwi i=puaka | \gls 1SG=see DEF.SG=man REL=3SG=eat DEF.SG=pig | \glt I see the man who is biting the pig.
Content 2: \gll e=xaleke i=apuli a=a=xhwi puaka | \gls 1SG=see DEF.SG=man REL=3SG=eat pig | \glt I see the man who is eating pork. (not: the/a/some pig)
Content 3: \gll lu=xa-tena apuli | \gls 3DU=HAB-understand person | \glt They understand people.

Knowledge Point: Consider example (\ref{ex:t1}) from a French\hyp language legend, written by Yvonne Sahilé, and translated by the workgroup into Vamale. The example translates \qu{il y avait une tribu} (there was a tribe) using i \qu{\gl{def}.\gl{sg}}, making it seem more specific than definite, since the listeners cannot yet be familiar with the tribe. My first suggestion was using an indefinite article eca (\ref{ex:wrongtipije}), which was refused. %The whole text is too long to be shown here, but see the document "conte".
Content 1: \gll Habu Can-Vije vwa \textbf{i}=apemoo a= pwa-n jela \textbf{i}=jahoot a= xhopwen. | \gls long.ago Tipije exist DEF.SG=tribe REL= on-NSPEC side DEF.SG=river REL= big | \glt Long ago in the Tipije valley, there was a tribe on the bank of this great river. (following the French original text) {[1]}
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: Now look at example (\ref{ex:t1}), where the tribe has never been mentioned before, compared to examples (\ref{ex:t2}) and (\ref{ex:t3}), where it has. All sentences use the same article. In (\ref{ex:t3}), li thamo \qu{the women} are newly introduced to the narrative but marked with the definite li. %It could be argued that there are always young women in a village, but the previous argument of saliency to the situation seems to justify an analysis as definite well enough.
Content 1: \gll Habu Can-Vije vwa \textbf{i}=apemoo a= pwa-n jela \textbf{i}=jahoot a= xhopwen. | \gls long.ago Tipije exist DEF.SG=tribe REL= on-NSPEC side DEF.SG=river REL= big | \glt Long ago in the Tipije valley, there was a tribe on the bank of this great river. (following the French original text) {[1]}
Content 2: \gll Ca i=apemoo-ca le=vacuti \textbf{ca} daahma a= bwa xawe, ka yata-n Thêa Xa-vila | \gls in DEF.SG=tribe-PROX 3PL=erect some chief REL= IPFV young and name-3SG.POSS T. NMLZ-dance | \glt In this tribe they erected a chief who was still young, and his name was Firstborn the Dancer. (Thêa is a name commonly given to the firstborn son) {[2]}
Content 3: \gll Ca \textbf{i}=apemoo vwa \textbf{li}=xawe thamo | \gls in DEF.SG=tribe EXIST DEF.PL=young woman | \glt In the tribe were young women. (indefinite, non-specific in the French original) {[3]}
Content 4: \gll Ca \textbf{i}=apemoo vwa \textbf{li}=xawe thamo | \gls in DEF.SG=tribe EXIST DEF.PL=young woman | \glt In the tribe were young women. (indefinite, non-specific in the French original) {[3]}

Knowledge Point: This description analyzes i \qu{\gl{def}.\gl{sg}} and li \qu{\gl{def}.\gl{pl}} as definite articles, using \textcite{lyons_definiteness_1999}'s definition. Noun phrases marked with i and li are identifiable \parencite[1]{lyons_definiteness_1999}, albeit not necessarily familiar \parencite[3]{lyons_definiteness_1999}, see (\ref{ex:t2}) and (\ref{ex:t3}). Familiarity, to Lyons, is not an necessary feature for a construction to be definite \parencite[5]{lyons_definiteness_1999}. As Lyons discusses in the pages following that statement, the uniqueness of a referent, in total or relative to the context \parencite[8]{lyons_definiteness_1999}, or even ``the totality of the objects [\ldots] in the context which satisfy the description'' \parencite[11]{lyons_definiteness_1999}, can all be grounds for definiteness.
Content 1: \gll Ca i=apemoo-ca le=vacuti \textbf{ca} daahma a= bwa xawe, ka yata-n Thêa Xa-vila | \gls in DEF.SG=tribe-PROX 3PL=erect some chief REL= IPFV young and name-3SG.POSS T. NMLZ-dance | \glt In this tribe they erected a chief who was still young, and his name was Firstborn the Dancer. (Thêa is a name commonly given to the firstborn son) {[2]}
Content 2: \gll Ca \textbf{i}=apemoo vwa \textbf{li}=xawe thamo | \gls in DEF.SG=tribe EXIST DEF.PL=young woman | \glt In the tribe were young women. (indefinite, non-specific in the French original) {[3]}

Knowledge Point: Example (\ref{ex:t4-6}) describes a woman not previously mentioned, \textit{\textbf{eca} thamo a en maa-n} \qu{she who has a beautiful face}: indefinite but specific. Example (\ref{ex:t7}) describes a similar situation: In-Thu is a unique, identifiable character, not previously introduced. However, the relative clause modifying her is defining, and so preceded by i, whereas the one in (\ref{ex:t4-6}) is not, and its modified noun takes eca. %The use of definite i instead of indefinite eca may be a de-grammaticalized one, however: eca is not attested before defining relative clauses, but can occur before an indefinite.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll le=kiica ka meeka \textbf{li}=been thamo, ma ca-n e-dawee-le \textbf{i}=a= yata-n In Thu. | \gls 3PL=jealous and all DEF.PL=other woman COM in-INDF MID-between-3PL DEF.SG=REL= name-3SG.POSS skin banyan | \glt All the other women were jealous, with among them all the one who was called Banyan Bark.

Knowledge Point: Example (\ref{ex:t2}) seems to use ca in an indefinite way, too, introducing a character who is then further specified and named. %But is it specific? They could have elected some chief, whoever he was, and only afterwards is it explained how he is called.
Content 1: \gll Ca i=apemoo-ca le=vacuti \textbf{ca} daahma a= bwa xawe, ka yata-n Thêa Xa-vila | \gls in DEF.SG=tribe-PROX 3PL=erect some chief REL= IPFV young and name-3SG.POSS T. NMLZ-dance | \glt In this tribe they erected a chief who was still young, and his name was Firstborn the Dancer. (Thêa is a name commonly given to the firstborn son) {[2]}

Knowledge Point: Vamale distinguishes specific from generic participants using articles (except for pronouns and proper names). The articles mark number and definiteness, and, through their presence, specificity. The criteria for definite noun phrases include identifiability and uniqueness, as shown in (\ref{ex:t4-6}), where a woman is introduced as one of many, compared to the obligatorily definite introduction of the unique village in (\ref{ex:t1}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll Habu Can-Vije vwa \textbf{i}=apemoo a= pwa-n jela \textbf{i}=jahoot a= xhopwen. | \gls long.ago Tipije exist DEF.SG=tribe REL= on-NSPEC side DEF.SG=river REL= big | \glt Long ago in the Tipije valley, there was a tribe on the bank of this great river. (following the French original text) {[1]}

Knowledge Point: The article eca cannot co-occur with any of the definite articles i, mu, li, nor with a demonstrative pronoun in the same phrase.\footnote{The adverb eca-ve \qu{some-where} probably combines the stative verb ve \qu{where? (immobile)} with the article, as does eca-se \qu{some-one} (\ref{ex:eca}).} \Cref{tab:Pwpw} also suggests that ca-forms are used as articles, with la cognates in Hienghène-linkage languages.
Content 1: \gll eca-aman | \gls some-thing | \glt something% (aman is also a placeholder for arguments of certain verbs, like xhwi aman eat something)

Knowledge Point: While eca is used in compounds with singular meaning (\ref{ex:eca}), the distinction between singular and plural indefinite articles is becoming blurry.
Content 1: \gll eca-aman | \gls some-thing | \glt something% (aman is also a placeholder for arguments of certain verbs, like xhwi aman eat something)

Knowledge Point: Ca \qu{\gl{indf}.\gl{pl}} is distinguished by older speakers from eca \qu{\gl{indf}.\gl{sg}}, but not anymore by many younger speakers, where the two forms are in relatively free variation. The extent to which this distinction is still important is illustrated in the examples (\ref{ex:ca_eca_old}). According to Jeo Kalène (40 years old),\footnote{Recorded on 12.11.2018, see the archive.} eca is the singular and ca the plural indefinite article (\ref{ex:ca_eca_old}).
Content 1: \gll tha vwa eca=apuli a= a=vwa hmwaena | \gls ASS EXIST some.SG=person REL= 3SG=do thus.DIST | \glt There is a person who does it like this.
Content 2: \gll tha vwa eca=apuli a= a=vwa hmwaena | \gls ASS EXIST some.SG=person REL= 3SG=do thus.DIST | \glt There is a person who does it like this.

Knowledge Point: %Maybe example \ref{ex:ca_oven} is different from example \ref{ex:ca_field}, and more akin to \ref{ex:ca_xhuam}. In \ref{ex:ca_oven} and \ref{ex:ca_xhuam}, ca refers to parts of uncountable \qu{masses} (food in one case, things to put in her oven in the other). It is probably related to ca(-n) \qu{in (it)} (see \ref{ex:t2}). In \ref{ex:ca_field}, ca refers to a place, but more importantly, it does not modify a noun. The clause in brackets is subordinate to hân fwadai \qu{go look for it} and la \qu{be here} is anaphoric, but does it refer to ca, or something implied? ca is a preposition for nouns with an article.
Content 1: \gll ma cika vuki-n ma a=xaahni \textbf{ca}=aman ma a=vwa tââ-n | \gls SUBR NEG.EXIST reason-POSS SUBR 3SG=look.for INDF.PL=thing SUBR 3SG=make oven-3SG.POSS | \glt So that there was no reason for her to seek something to make her oven (with) (i.e. cook).
Content 2: \gll i=bwaabwen-an a=ja han fwadai \textbf{ca}i= [ma a=vwa nyangan-aman lai] | \gls DEF.SG=morning-POSS 3SG=PRF go search.INAN some= SUBR 3SG=do garden-something be.here | \glt The next day (lit. its morning) she finally went to look for some place to make her field.
Content 3: \gll fe ca=xhua-m | \gls take ART.INDF.PL=food-2PL.POSS | \glt Take some food (lit. Take some of your foodstuff).
Content 4: \gll ma cika vuki-n ma a=xaahni \textbf{ca}=aman ma a=vwa tââ-n | \gls SUBR NEG.EXIST reason-POSS SUBR 3SG=look.for INDF.PL=thing SUBR 3SG=make oven-3SG.POSS | \glt So that there was no reason for her to seek something to make her oven (with) (i.e. cook).
Content 5: \gll fe ca=xhua-m | \gls take ART.INDF.PL=food-2PL.POSS | \glt Take some food (lit. Take some of your foodstuff).
Content 6: \gll Ca i=apemoo-ca le=vacuti \textbf{ca} daahma a= bwa xawe, ka yata-n Thêa Xa-vila | \gls in DEF.SG=tribe-PROX 3PL=erect some chief REL= IPFV young and name-3SG.POSS T. NMLZ-dance | \glt In this tribe they erected a chief who was still young, and his name was Firstborn the Dancer. (Thêa is a name commonly given to the firstborn son) {[2]}
Content 7: \gll i=bwaabwen-an a=ja han fwadai \textbf{ca}i= [ma a=vwa nyangan-aman lai] | \gls DEF.SG=morning-POSS 3SG=PRF go search.INAN some= SUBR 3SG=do garden-something be.here | \glt The next day (lit. its morning) she finally went to look for some place to make her field.

Knowledge Point: Cabeen, probably from ca been \qu{some others, some of them}, see (\ref{ex:ca_been}), is for 25-year-old Jean-Philippe Oué the unambiguous plural form of eca, whereas ca is a free variant of eca, but can also be used for the plural. A similar confusion is found in the examples below, which stem from the translated legend (the translators were all around 40–50 years old). The article in (\ref{ex:ca_oven}) could refer to plural or singular entities, but in (\ref{ex:ca_field}) would more refer signify a single place.
Content 1: \gll e=xaje ca=been | \gls 1SG=eat.juicy INDF.PL=peer | \glt I ate some of them.
Content 2: \gll ma cika vuki-n ma a=xaahni \textbf{ca}=aman ma a=vwa tââ-n | \gls SUBR NEG.EXIST reason-POSS SUBR 3SG=look.for INDF.PL=thing SUBR 3SG=make oven-3SG.POSS | \glt So that there was no reason for her to seek something to make her oven (with) (i.e. cook).
Content 3: \gll i=bwaabwen-an a=ja han fwadai \textbf{ca}i= [ma a=vwa nyangan-aman lai] | \gls DEF.SG=morning-POSS 3SG=PRF go search.INAN some= SUBR 3SG=do garden-something be.here | \glt The next day (lit. its morning) she finally went to look for some place to make her field.

Knowledge Point: Since number is not marked on nouns, both (\ref{ex:ca_oven}) above and (\ref{ex:ca_xhuam}) below may actually denote non-singular rather than plural, since both refer to non-singular, possibly uncountable referents.
Content 1: \gll ma cika vuki-n ma a=xaahni \textbf{ca}=aman ma a=vwa tââ-n | \gls SUBR NEG.EXIST reason-POSS SUBR 3SG=look.for INDF.PL=thing SUBR 3SG=make oven-3SG.POSS | \glt So that there was no reason for her to seek something to make her oven (with) (i.e. cook).
Content 2: \gll fe ca=xhua-m | \gls take ART.INDF.PL=food-2PL.POSS | \glt Take some food (lit. Take some of your foodstuff).

Knowledge Point: %One more form was recorded once: kane \gl{def}.\gl{pl}=in modern Pije (ni in 1970s). Used by one person in Vamale once (her parents speak Pije), see example \ref{ex:kane}. This seems at the very least to indicate that the system is not as rigid as it used to be.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The definite articles i and li can derive relative clauses to nouns (\ref{ex:art_RC}).
Content 1: \gll le=vwa ma le=thabilo li=a= le=fee-ko | \gls 3PL=do SUBR 3PL=strike DEF.PL=REL= 3PL=take-2SG.OBJ | \glt They want to kill those who took you.

Knowledge Point: Demonstrative pronouns have nominal status in the sense that they function syntactically as nouns including case marking, except that they cannot take articles. Vamale demonstratives distinguish proximal and distal (see \Cref{tab:demonstratives}), making the system somewhat simpler than the regional three-way average \parencite[38]{lynch_oceanic_2002}. They are a closed class of six forms, whose members are only partially transparent. All forms contain a distal or proximal suffix, and the dual forms still carry as a stem the dual article mu. The plural forms' stem ni is identical to the plural article in Usa Vamale and other Voh-Koné varieties \parencite[42]{rivierre_bwatoo_2006} discussed in \sectref{ssec:ni}, and is accepted by most speakers of Vamale as well. The segment e- in the singular forms may derive from the singular article i and the plural forms could be composed of plural article ni and the singular, already lexicalised form. Demonstrative pronouns can serve both as topic and comment, as in (\ref{ex:WCdem}).
Content 1: \gll cahma \textbf{ehni} a=mu tua tua i=aman | \gls TOP DEM.PROX 3SG=FREQ unwrap unwrap DEF.SG=thing | \glt But him, he was unwrapping, unwrapping the thing.

Knowledge Point: The demonstrative pronoun na is special, because it can be used as a presentative (``this is Liline"), and to mark the comment of an equational clause (\ref{ex:na_topic1}, \ref{ex:na_topic2}). Since hni does not exist (anymore), na is neither proximal nor distal, and functions as a more neutral pronoun.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll Jacob tha juu xa-vee ma hmwaana. \textbf{na} hmwaana, go=xaleke? | \gls J. ASS real NMLZ.AGT-fuck SUBR thus DEM thus 2SG=see | \glt Jacob, it's bad for him if it's like this. That's how it is, you see?

Knowledge Point: Relational nouns are the functional equivalent of spatial prepositions in Vamale, meaning they are the head of a phrase. Their modifier\slash possessor is the location in which the noun phrase or verb phrase's referent is located (\ref{ex:pwa1}). The members of this closed class are possessed (mostly inalienably) and cannot take an article. They are included with nouns because of their historical relationship to nouns % xxaskAlexElias
Content 1: \gll a=xheela-ta pwa-n ye | \gls 3SG=crawl-go.up on-INDF tree | \glt He tree-climbs.

Knowledge Point: Some of the relational nouns are derived from nouns using a devoicing of the first consonant, e.g. bwa-n \qu{head, top} \rightarrow pwa-n \qu{on top}, jela-n \qu{side} \rightarrow cela-n \qu{next to}. This phenomenon is also described for Cèmuhî \parencite[37]{rivierre_langue_1980}. Inalienably possessed relational nouns like xala-n \qu{under} all lose their final -n if followed by a specific argument (\ref{ex:pwa}).
Content 1: \gll a=xheela-ta pwa i=ye | \gls 3SG=crawl-go.up on DEF.SG=tree | \glt He climbs the tree/a tree.

Knowledge Point: The forms are independent pronouns in the sense that they can take up the same slot as a nominal phrase. The difference to subject marker clitics is that the pronouns cannot co-occur with another noun phrase that has the same syntactic function. Subject index clitics are always present (except in imperatives, or in stative verbs with inanimate subjects). This means that, at least following the Uniqueness Condition asking for each grammatical relation to be assigned only once within its clause (after \cite[19]{kroeger_analyzing_2004}), subject indexing clitics (or ``bound pronouns") and free personal pronouns are not allomorphs. Compare to \Cref{tab:markers}. Pronouns can take subject markers (see example \ref{ex:PNcase}), but not articles.
Content 1: \gll e=vii ka yo | \gls 1SG=say SBJ 1SG | \glt I say.

Knowledge Point: As mentioned in \sectref{sec:WCPersPron}, Vamale uses proclitics derived from free pronominal forms, in order to index subject NPs on active verbs (see \Cref{tab:markers}). Note that stative verbs mark the intransitive subject much like alienable possessums do (compare \Cref{tab:PossSuffix1}). The clitics occur before active verbal, or nominal predicates, in the slot left of the TAM markers. The pair yo \textasciitilde e= \qu{1\gl{sg}} is the same in Cèmuhî \parencite[61]{rivierre_langue_1980}, but not in other Voh-Koné languages. The other markers are transparently Voh-Koné, and almost identical with the western varieties: \ort{zha} [ða] \textasciitilde \ort{a} [a] \qu{3\gl{sg}} is described for Bwatoo as well \parencite[31]{rivierre_bwatoo_2006}. The sound correspondence [ð] \textasciitilde [j] is a regular one between coastal and mountain varieties. Note that while the bound pronouns are mostly very similar to the free pronouns, they can co-occur in the same clause (\ref{ex:subject_index}), which is a sign that they do not have the same syntactic role: the free forms are true pronouns, whereas the bound pronouns have become grammaticalized to subject indexes on predicates.% the free form ya \qu{3\gl{sg}} seems to be a loan from the Pije form nyang or Fwâi yak \qu{3\gl{sg}} \parencite[246]{haudricourt_dictionnaire_1982}.
Content 1: \gll e=xale-le ka yo | \gls 1SG=see-3PL.OBJ SBJ 1SG | \glt I see them.

Knowledge Point: Prepositions are derived from inalienable nominal forms (but do not take articles) and, similarly to relational nouns (see \sectref{ssec:WCPrepoNouns}), they can have generic or specific markers. There are only four prepositions: ko \qu{lit. on} \qu{\gl{obl}}, si \qu{for (human)} (illustrated in \ref{ex:si}), nya-si \qu{lit. put/place-hand} \qu{for (human)} (see \ref{ex:nyasi2a}), nya-ko \qu{lit. put/place-on}, \qu{for (all)}. Forms with ko are lengthened when generic or anaphoric (i.e. koo-n), and not followed by a NP. Since the markers cannot be modified, lack lexical content, and attach to noun phrases, I call them particles. A more detailed description is found in \sectref{ssec:nyako}.
Content 1: \gll a=nya balan-o si li=thamo ka i=xa-vwa-o | \gls 3SG=put piece.of.length-bamboo BEN DEF.PL=woman SBJ DEF.SG=AGT.NMLZ-do-bamboo | \glt The bamboo cutter hands bamboo poles to the women.
Content 2: \gll tha lu=mata nyasi i=jamwa-n sohmu-n | \gls ASS 3DU=sing for DEF.SG=father-POSS study-NSPEC | \glt They sing for the teacher.

Knowledge Point: The subject marker ka marks the subject noun phrase (\ref{ex:kawc}). On the grounds that it is part of the noun phrase, but does not attach to any specific word class, that it is phonologically part of its host structure, and that it can itself not be modified or fronted, it is a proclitic. Obligatory for A arguments and optional for S (this is probably a more recent development), ka can also be used to mark a focused possessor, though this is rare. A ka marked noun phrase cannot be fronted. This distinguishes ka from \gl{obl} markers and phrase heads ko \qu{at, to}, nyako \qu{at, to, for}, and nyasi \qu{for}, which are hence considered both p- and g-words, whereas ka is not only dependent on a noun phrase, but also on the latter's unmarked post-predicate position. See \sectref{ssec:ka} for a detailed description.
Content 1: \gll go=thêên ka=go | \gls 2SG=run SBJ=2SG | \glt You run.

Knowledge Point: The relativizer a introduces a relative clause subordinated to a noun phrase (\ref{ex:rel}). It is sometimes left out. It is probably related to a \qu{3\gl{sg}}.\footnote{The relativizers in Cèmuhî are related to the plural article li and proximal naa \parencite[92]{rivierre_langue_1980}. The relativizer in Bwatoo is the same as in Vamale \parencite[473, 486]{rivierre_bwatoo_2006}.} Relative clauses can be derived to nouns by an article (\ref{ex:rela}).
Content 1: \gll e=thapi i=iila a= a=vwa | \gls 1SG=break DEF.SG=pot REL= 3SG=do | \glt I break the pot that he made.
Content 2: \gll li=a= le=vwa-sukin | \gls DEF.PL=REL= 3PL=do-price | \glt Those who shop.

Knowledge Point: As the relativizer and the third person singular are both a, they usually merge (\ref{ex:rel_merg}).
Content 1: \gll e=xaleke i=apuli \textbf{a}=\textbf{a}=xhwi puaka | \gls 1SG=see DEF.SG=man REL=3SG=eat pig | \glt I see the man who is eating pork.

Knowledge Point: Vamale has around a dozen morphemes used to situate an event relative to its temporal context (aspect), to the speaker moment (tense), and to reality in general (mood). Most of them are aspectual markers. Although Vamale traditionally does not seem to have expressed tense, this is nowadays done with bwa \qu{\gl{ipfv}} and (b)o \qu{\gl{irr}} for future tense. Most of the morphemes listed here and described in Chapter \ref{ChapterAspect} are used for several functions, and this is the case for all mood functions (e.g. balan \qu{\gl{cont}} and bo \qu{\gl{irr}}, but also ja \qu{finally}). Syntactically speaking, all of the TAM markers proper are particles: though they directly precede the predicate (and follow the subject index proclitics), and though most cannot be fronted, they can be stressed. They can combine with other TAM markers to form either transparent or idiosyncratic new meanings (\ref{ex:bwakon}). Their meaning depends on the word class of the predicate's head and the aktionsart of the verb.
Content 1: \gll e=bwa kon vii | \gls 1SG=IPFV PROG say | \glt I am still saying.

Knowledge Point: The phasal negator ban \qu{not yet} is a TAM marker as it takes a slot between the subject marker and the verb (\ref{ex:ban1}). It only occurs after the negator cipa. Ban may be related to bwa \qu{\gl{ipfv}}, which in negated verb phrases has the allomorph bwan. A reviewer suggested to analyze it as an incompletive aspect marker. This would simplify the analysis, but the term is more often used to describe actions which have begun but not been completed \parencite{overall_typology_2017}, which is not the case here.%ban was elicited
Content 1: \gll cipa go=ban han xaleke | \gls NEG 2SG=not.yet go see | \glt You never went to see.

Section: Verbs% (take SUBJ= and TAM), %how do I disambiguate this from other things? SUBJ= and TAM works for all predicates, really
Knowledge Point: While the proclitics will also attach to nominal predicates, they are optional for nouns, whereas verbs require them in non-imperative settings. Contrary to nouns, verbs cannot take articles. Verbs take derivational morphemes like causative fa-, reflexive e-, and attenuative the-. The animacy of participants influences whether participants are indexed on the verb; inanimate referents do not trigger stative subject suffixes (\ref{ex:WCstat_inan}) nor object suffixes. %\includegraphics[\width=\linewidth]{figures/alignment}
Content 1: \gll sinu (i=xh-ong) | \gls suffer (DEF.SG=leg-1SG.POSS) | \glt (My leg) hurts.

Section: Verbs% (take SUBJ= and TAM), %how do I disambiguate this from other things? SUBJ= and TAM works for all predicates, really
Knowledge Point: Participant indexing on verbs thus displays split-intransitive alignment: active verbs index transitive and intransitive subjects identically while distinguishing objects (\ref{ex:alignment1}, \ref{ex:alignment2}). Stative verbs do not index their invariably intransitive subject like active verbs do (\ref{ex:alignment3}), nor do their suffixes overlap with undergoer marking on transitive verbs (\ref{ex:alignment1}). An illustration is given in \Cref{fig:verb_alignment}.
Content 1: \gll e=xhwii-ko | \gls 1SG=bite-2SG.OBJ | \glt I bite you.
Content 2: \gll e=thana | \gls 1SG=wander | \glt I wander around.
Content 3: \gll sinu-go | \gls suffer-2SG | \glt You are ill, you suffer.

Knowledge Point: Vamale possesses a small class of adverbs. They occur at the end of a clause or phrase, are frequently fronted without a phrase (\ref{ex:Adv}), take neither articles nor any kind of possessive or inflectional morphology, and are, if at all, modified by the intensifiers described in \sectref{sec:WCIntensifiers}, juu \qu{real, really, very}. As they modify verb, noun, and prepositional phrases, and as they can be fronted alone, this analysis considers them to be adjuncts. Most members are transparently derived from nouns or prepositional phrases. See \sectref{sec:Adv} for examples of their interaction with verb and noun phrases. Example (\ref{ex:Adv}) features two cases of fronted adverbs, (\ref{ex:Adv2}) shows an adverb at the end of a verb phrase, and (\ref{ex:Adv3}) shows an adverb after noun phrase.\largerpage[-2]
Content 1: \gll ka {\ob}jethro{\cb} \textbf{canbwen} man \textbf{bwethalo} {\ob}le=cuut cahni ka ni=bee-m-ca{\cb}, \textbf{cahni} {\ob}ca-n xhoogo{\cb} | \gls CNJ J. yesterday COM two.days.ago 3PL=stand here SBJ DEF.PL=peer-2SG.POSS-PROX here in-NSPEC home | \glt And Jethro, yesterday and the day before your relatives stood here, here at home.
Content 2: \gll ka {\ob}jethro{\cb} \textbf{canbwen} man \textbf{bwethalo} {\ob}le=cuut cahni ka ni=bee-m-ca{\cb}, \textbf{cahni} {\ob}ca-n xhoogo{\cb} | \gls CNJ J. yesterday COM two.days.ago 3PL=stand here SBJ DEF.PL=peer-2SG.POSS-PROX here in-NSPEC home | \glt And Jethro, yesterday and the day before your relatives stood here, here at home.
Content 3: \gll e=ha-mwa \textbf{canbwen} | \gls 1SG=go-REP yesterday | \glt I went back yesterday.
Content 4: \gll na i=vaaya-n xayu \textbf{habu} ka | \gls DEM DEF.SG=work-POSS man before DISC | \glt This was a man's work back then, like.

Knowledge Point: Temporal adverbs are a closed class of words that can occur in a fronted position (\ref{ex:tempadv}). They cannot take articles. Temporal adverbs were almost all derived from nominals, compare bwaabwen \qu{morning} is related to the adverb bwaabwen-an \qu{in the morning after}. Members include ca-n-bwen \qu{yesterday (lit. \qu{in-\gl{nspec}-night})}, naen \qu{today/now}, xahmaen \qu{tomorrow}\footnote{Proto (Southern) Oceanic *marani \parencite[314]{lynch_efate-erromango_2004}.}, jimin \qu{late at night (after having fallen asleep)}, bwethaloo \qu{two days ago}, thaloobwen \qu{overmorrow (lit. `two nights')}, daboo-n bwen \qu{midnight (`lit. puddle/lake of the night')} %19-07-18, page 34)
Content 1: \gll na li=peintures habu | \gls DEM DEF.PL=paint before | \glt It's the (style of) painting from the old days.

Knowledge Point: A closed class of words describes locations. They are mostly derived from movement verbs.\footnote{Patemwano \qu{directly next to it}, ngangeno \qu{close-by} in Pije \parencite[170]{haudricourt_dictionnaire_1982} and puput \qu{behind (a building or a sizeable entity)} can be used in the same slots but do not possess the morphological combinatorics shown in \Cref{tab:LocAdv}.} They do not bear articles, can be fronted alone (\ref{ex:front_xahut}), and can modify verbs (\ref{ex:xahut1}) as well as nouns (\ref{ex:LocAdvPred}). Locative adverbs can be predicates, see (\ref{ex:LocAdvPred}). Contrary to relational nouns (\sectref{ssec:WCPrepoNouns}), locative adverbs do not form possessive relations with nouns, nor do they take generic -n. \Cref{tab:LocAdv} shows a summary of the forms. For a more thorough account of space (see \sectref{ssec:spat_adv}).
Content 1: \gll xahut, go=majit mati | \gls below 2SG=rest earlier | \glt Down there, you were sleeping earlier.
Content 2: \gll go=moo xahut, go=xahut, go=hut xahut | \gls 2SG=stay below 2SG=below 2SG=go.down below | \glt You live down there, you're down there, you go down there.
Content 3: \gll i=apuli (a=) xahut | \gls DEF.SG=man (3SG=) below | \glt The man is down there.
Content 4: \gll i=apuli (a=) xahut | \gls DEF.SG=man (3SG=) below | \glt The man is down there.

Knowledge Point: hman \qu{also} modifies verbs (\ref{ex:hmanV}), nouns (\ref{ex:hman}), and adverbs. Contrary to temporal and locative adverbs, hman always comes after the modified word and cannot be fronted on its own. Similarly to mwa (\sectref{sec:mwa}), hman is used as a discourse marker as well, with a meaning of \qu{however} (\ref{ex:hmanDisc}).
Content 1: \gll tha gau=han tha gau tha gase=bo arriver hman | \gls ASS 2DU=go ASS 2DU ASS 1PL.INCL=IRR arrive also | \glt You go (despite the height of the steel beam), you two, we'll get (to the other side), too.
Content 2: \gll li=meeka i=\ldots li=nyan-mwa ca-n {hman} | \gls DEF.PL=all DEF.SG=\ldots DEF.PL=inside-house in-ANA also | \glt All the rooms in the house as well.
Content 3: \gll thake yavo kavi tha cipa xhwii hman | \gls throw fishing.line but ASS NEG bite also | \glt ...threw out the fishing line but it didn't bite though.

Knowledge Point: Clauses that are complement to verbs of cognition (\ref{ex:hapi2}), opinion, and perception (\ref{ex:hapi3}), are introduced by the subordinator hapi. Considering \textcite{lynch_oceanic_2002}'s observation that Oceanic languages tend to use a form related or identical to the word \qu{to say} to introduce complement clauses \parencite[53]{lynch_oceanic_2002}, that Voh-Koné languages changed p- \rightarrow v-, and that Hienghène languages have peei \qu{to say}, \qu{\gl{comp}} \parencite[260]{haudricourt_dictionnaire_1982}, postulating a=vii \qu{s/he says} as the origin of hapi seems plausible.
Content 1: \gll e=caihna-n hapi tha hmwaana | \gls 1SG=know-NSPEC COMP ASS thus | \glt I know that it's like that.
Content 2: \gll sahnaang-eong hapi tha hmwaana | \gls not.understand-1SG COMP ASS thus | \glt I'm not sure/I doubt that it's like that.

Knowledge Point: Nominal conjunctions connect noun (phrases) and form a new constituent containing the connected noun phrases and the conjunction. Members include ma `and\slash with' (\ref{ex:maconj}), ka `on the other hand' (\ref{ex:kaconj}), hai \textasciitilde a \qu{or} (\ref{ex:haiconj1}) with its derivative hai...hai \qu{either...or} (\ref{ex:haiconj}), moko \qu{more than}. Moko may be complex and composed of moo \qu{rest, reside} and ko \qu{on} (\sectref{sec:Comp}). It has no Hienghène cognate. The other Voh-Koné varieties share the form, however. \citet[215]{rivierre_bwatoo_2006} suggest a makeup of mo \qu{from}, as in \textit{e ha-me \textbf{mo} Tuo} \qu{I come \textbf{from} Touho}, and ko \qu{on}.
Content 1: \gll i=wabatan ma i=xat | \gls DEF.SG=north.wind and DEF.SG=sun | \glt `the north wind and the sun'
Content 2: \gll i=wabatan ka i=xat | \gls DEF.SG=north.wind and DEF.SG=sun | \glt `the north wind, and (on the other hand) the sun'
Content 3: \gll i=wabatan hai i=xat | \gls DEF.SG=north.wind or DEF.SG=sun | \glt`the north wind or the sun'
Content 4: \gll hai i=wabatan hai i=xat | \gls or DEF.SG=north.wind or DEF.SG=sun | \glt either the north wind or the sun

Knowledge Point: The set of verbal conjunctions is small and closed, and groups together some morphemes which only occur in this set, like kavi \qu{but}, with words also present in other distributional classes. The meaning distinctions between kavi \qu{but (introducing something in contrast with the former element)}, ko \qu{but [introducing something unexpected)}, and ma \qu{but (relaying something related but different)} are fine and depend on the context. Members include ka `and' (\ref{ex:kaVC}), kavi `but' (\ref{ex:kaviVC}), ma `and, but' (\ref{ex:maVC}), hai \goodtilde a `or' (\ref{ex:haiVC}), ko \qu{but}, \qu{because}, kona \qu{furthermore}.
Content 1: \gll le=hame ka le=siwa=mwa | \gls 3PL=come and 3PL=return=REP | \glt `They came and they left again.'
Content 2: \gll le=hame kavi le=siwa-mwa | \gls 3PL=come but 3PL=return-REP | \glt `They came but they left again.'
Content 3: \gll le=ha-me ma le=siwa-mwa | \gls 3PL=go-DIR.CP and 3PL=return-REP | \glt `They come and/in order to go.'
Content 4: \gll le=ha-me hai le=siwa=mwa | \gls 3PL=go-DIR.CP or 3PL=return=REP | \glt `They come or they go.'

Knowledge Point: Ka is also used colloquially after a clause to ask for confirmation (\ref{ex:kaDisc}) (see \sectref{discourse ka}).
Content 1: \gll i=apuli a=xahan ka? | \gls DEF.SG=person REL=over.there DISC | \glt The guy over there, like?

Knowledge Point: Numbers are verbal, and (na)-bwa \qu{plus} (possibly from \gl{dem}-\qu{head}, \ref{ex:nabwa}), and ko \qu{times} (probably from ko \qu{on}) are used to construct complex numbers (\ref{ex:nabwako}).
Content 1: \gll nim na-bwa se | \gls 5 plus 1 | \glt 6
Content 2: \gll nim na-bwa se ko apuli nabwa nim na-bwa se | \gls 5 plus 1 times man/20 plus 5 plus 1 | \glt 126

Knowledge Point: Vamale subordinators introduce a subordinated clause. They precede all other elements of said clause, and cannot occur without the clause, moving with it if fronted, see examples (\ref{ex:fronted}--\ref{ex:frontedend}). All those ending on -a assimilate to following e= \qu{1\gl{sg}}. They are proclitics.
Content 1: \gll cel=e=hame go=pa yahan | \gls when=1SG=come 2SG=PRF leave | \glt `When I came, you had already left.'
Content 2: \gll ma le=fe, le=mu=xaahni | \gls as 3SG=take, 3PL=FREQ=check | \glt When they take it, they check it.

Knowledge Point: Non-fronted examples, illustrated in (\ref{ex:non-fronted}), are the norm.
Content 1: \gll tha=abe=saavi cama=abe icu-koo-n ko-n marché | \gls ASS=1PL.EXCL=dig.up SUBR=1PL.EXCL trade-OBL-ANA on-NSPEC market | \glt `We dig (them) up when we sell them on the market.' {[AG1:22]}

Knowledge Point: The negation markers cipa \qu{\gl{neg}} and cipii \qu{\gl{proh}} share their scope over the entire following clause and their left-most position. The negation markers are not identical in their distribution and could, strictly speaking, be classified into two separate classes. Contrary to cipa \qu{\gl{neg}} (\ref{ex:thacipa}), cipii \qu{\gl{proh}} cannot take assertive tha, nor na \qu{\gl{foc}}. Furthermore, cipii often omits the subject marker, which cipa cannot do (\ref{ex:cipi}). This grammar will treat cipa as a proclitic, because it integrates into the following verb phrase's stress structure, and assimilates phonologically to it as well (\ref{ex:cipa}).
Content 1: \gll (tha) cipa [go=bwaa=majit]? | \gls (ASS) NEG 2SG=IPFV=sleep | \glt Aren't you still asleep?
Content 2: \gll cipii xaloo koo-ng hmwaahni (ka go)! | \gls PROH gaze OBL-1SG.POSS thus SBJ 2SG | \glt Don't look at me like that!
Content 3: \gll cipa= e= majit | \gls NEG 1SG= sleep | \glt I don't sleep.

Knowledge Point: The assertive marker tha is a proclitic that docks onto the predicates of non-imperative clauses, on the left-most position (\ref{ex:tha1}). Tha assimilates to e= \qu{1\gl{sg}}, like cipa \qu{\gl{neg}} (\ref{ex:tha2}). %unlike na \qu{\gl{dem}}, pro-clitic to predicates.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll cala th=e vwa-tau | \gls when ASS=1SG do-impact | \glt when I fish

Knowledge Point: The two intensifiers juu \qu{real, very} and vaa \qu{(too) much} (most often preceded by juu, but see \ref{ex:vaa}) cannot stand alone, are semantically vague (see \Cref{tab:juu}), and attach to the head of a phrase (be that a noun, an adverb, or anything else, \ref{ex:juu}) as closely as possible. Given that they can be stressed, they are analyzed as particles, though ``anti-clitic" may be a better term considering the fact that they syntactically depend on a host that can be nominal, verbal, or adverbial in nature. Juu is also associated to bwa \qu{\gl{ipfv}}, as described in \sectref{ssec:bwa_ju}.
Content 1: \gll ma go=hmwaani vwasoon, ma go=hmwaani vaa... | \gls COND 2SG=like.this impossible COND 2SG=like.this too.much | \glt If you do it like this, it's impossible, and if you do it like this, it's too...
Content 2: \gll a=juu hnyimake ka i=juu apuli, juu ca-n-bwen | \gls 3SG=very think SBJ DEF.SG=real person real in-NSPEC-night | \glt `He thought hard, the real man, just yesterday.'

Knowledge Point: The particle vaa, depending on the word it modifies, means \qu{much (uncountable)} with non-human nouns (\ref{ex:vaa1}), %meaning \qu{many} for ants, in contrast to hmain, \qu{many} for humans.
Content 1: \gll e-vaa nya-da xa-da | \gls MID-INTS towards-up.there LOC.ADV-up | \glt There are many (feral pigs) up there.

Knowledge Point: intensifies the following verb, e.g. vaa thêên \qu{strongly run}\slash\qu{run fast}, and in combination with ju \qu{real, true}, it means \qu{too much}, as in (\ref{ex:vaa2}).
Content 1: \gll juu va vwasoon ma gase=vwa li=vaaya-n li=xhaohmu | \gls real much difficult COMP 1PL.INCL=do DEF.PL=work-POSS DEF.PL=elder | \glt It's too hard for us to do the work of the elders.

Knowledge Point: This class only has one member. Mwa has rather different, related meanings, depending on the context. Mwa can have the repetitive meaning \qu{again} (\ref{ex:mwa_even}), the restitutive \qu{back}, as well as \qu{also}, \qu{even}, \qu{on top of that}, or mark the preceding phrase as focused (see \sectref{sec:mwa} for a discussion). The deictic use of mwa \qu{now} (\ref{ex:mwa}), seems to mostly anchor the listener's attention, similarly to mwa \qu{even}, onto the noun phrase given, see (\ref{ex:mwa_now1a}). Mwa is a particle that can dock onto any phrase preceding it (see \ref{ex:mwa_rep}).
Content 1: \gll e=xaleke mwa | \gls 1SG=see REP | \glt `I see again.', `I even see.'
Content 2: \gll hê na tha vwa li=wii-n. go le=vwa ibi-han li=nyamaan go tha le=ve-moo mwa, moo mwa. | \gls yes DEM ASS EXIST DEF.PL=field-POSS.NSPEC then 3PL=do pinch-walk DEF.PL=eye then ASS 3PL=MID-stay REP stay REP | \glt Yes there were fields of it (macaranga vedeliana). And they'd go pinch the young sprouts. And those stay together now, stay.
Content 3: \gll ya a=ja vwa \textbf{mwa} li=wee-n a=ta-\textbf{mwa} sibu li=sibu \textbf{mwa}. ja yabwat \textbf{mwa} sisuu \textbf{mwa} | \gls EXPL 3SG=PRF do REP DEF.PL=water-POSS.NSPEC 3SG=go.up-REP swell DEF.PL=swell REP PRF dry REP hard DEICT | \glt And there's the sap that rises, swells, the swells there. It dries then, gets hard then.
Content 4: \gll e=vatipwe mwa nya-mwa si-m mwa i=mwani mwa | \gls 1SG=drop REP give-REP hand-2SG.POSS REP DEF.SG=money REP | \glt I pass on to you too this money as well.

Knowledge Point: In (\ref{ex:movV-mwa1}) and for all other movement verbs, as well as xhose \qu{do again}, mwa is analyzed as a suffix, i.e. as having fused with its host. First, mwa assimilates to the root, which it does not do in other contexts.\footnote{Xhosepwa suggests a dropped -t or -p. The Pije and Fwâi cognates khô-peei \qu{?-say} \parencite[155]{haudricourt_dictionnaire_1982} could be a diachronic hint at a morphologically complex, old Vamale form.} Compare hut-mwa \rightarrow /hupʷa/ \qu{go back down}, to hut=mwa \qu{go down again}.
Content 1: \gll go=ha-mwa-me | \gls 2SG=go=REP=DIR.CP | \glt You return to me, you come back.

Knowledge Point: The particle also expresses repetition (\ref{ex:mwa_rep1a}), and deictically referring to something close spatially or recently mentioned (which is probably a derived meaning), as in (\ref{ex:mwa_rep1b}). See \sectref{sec:mwa} for a more detailed description. %Also means "even, on top of that".
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: Quantifiers are a tiny group of particles that are not inflected, directly preceding an (article) noun construction: mu \qu{little}, jaa \qu{many} (\ref{ex:jaa}), and ju-vaa \qu{too much}, which is also attested as an intensifier in verb phrases (\ref{ex:juva}). Quantifiers denote number and are described in \sectref{ssec:Quant}. Other words have similar meanings, but are verbs, like hmai- \qu{many}. One quantifier similarly integrates the noun phrase, but bears possessive suffixes: meeka-n \qu{all}.
Content 1: \gll ja apuli canbwen | \gls many people yesterday | \glt (there were) more people yesterday (than now)
Content 2: \gll ju-vaa apuli | \gls too.much person | \glt too many people
